The training rule on arms akimbo

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

original: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū bāhuppacālakaṁ antaraghare gacchanti bāhuṁ olambentā …pe….
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū bāhuppacālakam antara ghare gacchanti bāhum olambentā pe
translated: the monks from the group of six were walking in inhabited areas with their arms akimbo.

analyzed: na bāhuppacālakam antara ghare gamissāmi iti sikkhā karaṇīyā ati
translated: “‘I will not walk in inhabited areas with my arms akimbo,’ this is how you should train.”
One should not walk in inhabited areas with one’s arms akimbo.
One should walk with one’s arms lowered.

original: Yo anādariyaṁ paṭicca bāhuppacālakaṁ antaraghare gacchati bāhuṁ olambento, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
analyzed: yaḥ anādariyam paṭicca bāhuppacālakam antaraghare gacchati bāhum olambentaḥ āpatti dukkaṭassa
translated: If a monk, out of disrespect, walks in an inhabited area with his arms akimbo, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
